bioghist.p: Marion Harlan Steele (1904-1985) was one of the pioneers of the American home economics movement, which began at the turn of the twentieth century. Ellen H. Richards founded the American Home Economics Association (AHEA) in 1909. Steele championed Richards’ philosophy about family, nutrition, and ecology, but especially devoted her efforts to the International Scholarship Program of AHEA (which became the American Association of Family and Consumer Sciences—AAFCS—in 1994). Steele attended the University of Delaware’s Women’s College, graduating in 1928 with a bachelor's degree in English. In 1928 she began working as secretary to Helen W. Atwater, the editor of AHEA's Journal of Home Economics. Atwater also served as Specialist in Home Economics for the States Relations Service of the USDA. After a number of promotions, Marion Steele became the journal's managing editor in 1946. Steele held that position until she retired in 1969.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers related to the AHEA, the Marion H. Steele Symposium, and records of Helen W. Atwater. AHEA records include copies of the AHEA Journal of Home Economics (1953, 1959, including 50th anniversary issue); extracts regarding the AHEA International Scholarship Students (1935-1969); copies of the National Magazine of Home Economics Student Clubs (1936-1942); the resume of Marion H. Steele; a booklet from the 14th annual Marion H. Steele Symposium (1999), with biographical information; a history of the AHEA; and photos, largely from the USDA and the US Bureau of Home Economics. The Atwater papers date from 1916 to the mid 1940s and include correspondence, printed bulletins, newspaper clippings, and typescripts of articles. There are also tributes and memorials for Atwater, and for Mildred Horton, the Executive Secretary of the AHEA.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
